courses.name: Introduction to Physical Therapy
courses.description: Acquaints students with the physical therapy profession including the required educational preparation, practice settings, sample interventions, current issues, trends and research. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Biology of Healthy Living
courses.description: (same as BIOMED 2420 and NEP 2420).  Biology of inactivity as a casual factor in chronic disease.

courses.name: Musculoskeletal Anatomy and Injury
courses.description: Study of human musculoskeletal anatomy, movement, common injury and physical therapy management. Graded on an A-F basis only.

courses.name: Principles of Physical Therapy
courses.description: History of physical therapy: the profession; basic skills: first aid, infection control, vital signs; medical terminology. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Physical Therapy
courses.description: Independent study, based upon educational goals, leading to completion of a project or paper. Specific objectives and time line developed with the supervision of a faculty member.

courses.name: Clinical Education IA
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PH_THR 7120). An introduction to clinical education in Physical Therapy: includes development of foundational clinical skills and behaviors as well as experience in the PhysZou clinical setting. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Clinical Education IB
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PH_THR 7150). Continuation of Clinical Education IA with further emphasis on current events in Physical Therapy as well as the professional attributes of communication, teamwork and problem solving. Required experience in PhysZou clinical setting. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Applied Neurophysiology for Allied Health Students
courses.description: (same as OC_THR 4240; cross-leveled with PH_THR 7240, OC_THR 7240). Principles of basic neurophysiology, emphasizing correlation of structure and function of the nervous system.

courses.name: Human Kinesiology
courses.description: (same as HTH_PR 4250). Study of principles of physical laws, biomechanics and anatomic structure relative to human movement. Applications through analysis of daily functional performance, exercise, and sport.

courses.name: Clinical Pathophysiology
courses.description: (same as OC_THR 4270; cross-leveled wiht PH_THR 7270, OC_THR 7270). Interdisciplinary and case-based examination of the pathophysiology, prevention and general health management of disease/injury across the lifespan encountered in occupational and physical therapy practice.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: successful completion of prior professional coursework

courses.name: Physical Agents
courses.description: Biophysics, theory and technique concerning the use of physical agents as adjuncts to exercise programs. Includes thermal, electrical, light, hydrotherapy and mechanical agents.

courses.name: Foundations of Therapeutic Exercise
courses.description: Physiological basis of exercise throughout the lifespan with emphasis on the musculoskeletal, neuromuscular, cardiovascular/pulmonary and integumentary systems and the effects of injury and disease on these systems.

courses.name: Medical Testing in Rehabilitation
courses.description: Diagnostic tests used by disciplines within and outside of  physical therapy.  Studies include laboratory, nuclear  medicine, radiologic, and motion analysis.  Emphasis placed on interpretation of results as they apply to physical therapy examination and intervention.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to students accepted into professional major

courses.name: Evidence-Based Practice
courses.description: Clinical research design and methods overview. Critical review of current and historically important professional literature. Effective writing related to clinically applicable research using computer and library resources. Identification of research questions.

courses.name: Applied Therapeutic Exercise
courses.description: Application of therapeutic exercise with an emphasis on evidenced-based exercise prescription, modes and techniques of exercise typically seen in rehabilitation.

courses.name: Movement Theory and Application
courses.description: Human sensorimotor development; motor learning; motor control theories; developmental and practical application to exercise; proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation.

courses.name: Bridging the Clinical-Research Gap
courses.description: This class focuses on theories of clinical decision making and Evidence-based Practice, their applications to the clinical setting and dissemination of such information to colleagues in professional forums.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Orthopedic Physical Therapy with Laboratory
courses.description: Physical therapy diagnosis, management, and prevention of disorders of the musculoskeletal system; basics of orthopedic manual therapy. Includes laboratory.

courses.name: Orthopedic Physical Therapy
courses.description: Physical therapy diagnosis, management, and prevention of disorders of the musculoskeletal system; continuation of orthopedic manual therapy emphasizing the axial skeleton; traction; massage; taping; sport-specific injury rehabilitation; orthotics.

courses.name: Pediatric Physical Therapy
courses.description: Physical therapy evaluation and treatment of children with movement dysfunction. Emphasis on therapeutic exercise.

courses.name: Rehabilitation of the Neurologically Impaired Adult
courses.description: Physical Therapy evaluation and treatment of adults who have incurred neurological deficits; emphasis on the restorative care of individuals following spinal cord injury, stroke, and traumatic head injury.

courses.name: Pharmacology in Rehabilitation
courses.description: Principles of pharmacology including pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicology of common drugs encountered in rehabilitation.  Emphasis on pharmacology related to the musculoskeletal, neuromuscular, cardiovascular/pulmonary and integumentary systems across the lifespan.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to students accepted into a professional major

courses.name: Special Readings in Physical Therapy
courses.description: Independent readings selected in consultation with supervising faculty member. Identified educational goals and activities; discussion, annotated bibliography or report.

courses.name: Directed Readings in Physical Therapy
courses.description: Selected readings on specific topics.

courses.name: Clinical Evaluation and Procedures with Laboratory
courses.description: Principles and procedures of basic evaluation methods and documentation: muscle strength, range of motion, muscle balance, posture, neurologic tests. Includes laboratory.

courses.name: Clinical Kinesiology with Laboratory
courses.description: Advanced Kinesiology addressing functional mobility; specifics of normal human gait; pathokinetics of gait. Assistive devices; wheelchairs; orthoses and prostheses. Includes laboratory.

courses.name: Clinical Education IA
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PH_THR 4120).  An introduction to clinical education in Physical Therapy; includes development of foundational clinical skills and behaviors as well as experience in PhysZou clinical setting. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Clinical Education IB
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PH_THR 4150). Continuation of Clinical Education IA with further emphasis on current events in Physical Therapy as well as the professional attributes of communication, teamwork and problem solving.  Required experience in PhysZou clinical setting. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Applied Neurophysiology for Allied Health Students
courses.description: (same as OC_THR 7240; cross-leveled with OC_THR 4240, PH_THR 4240). Principles of basic neurophysiology, emphasizing correlation of structure and function of the nervous system.

courses.name: Human Kinesiology
courses.description: (same as HTH_PR 4250, OC_THR 4220 or OC_THR 7220). Study of principles of physical laws, biomechanics and anatomic structure relative to human movement. Applications through analysis of daily functional performance, exercise, and sport.

courses.name: Clinical Pathophysiology
courses.description: (same as OC_THR 7270; cross-leveled with PH_THR 4270, OC_THR 4270)  Interdisciplinary and case-based examination of the pathophysiology, prevention and general health management of disease/injury across the lifespan encountered in occupational and physical therapy practice.

courses.name: Physical Agents
courses.description: Biophysics, theory and technique concerning the use of physical agents as adjuncts to exercise programs. Includes thermal, electrical, light, hydrotherapy and mechanical agents.

courses.name: Foundations of Therapeutic Exercise
courses.description: Physiologic basis of exercise throughout the lifespan with emphasis on the musculoskeletal, neuromuscular, cardiovascular/ pulmonary and integumentary systems and the effects of injury and disease on these systems.

courses.name: Medical Testing in Rehabilitation
courses.description: Diagnostic test used by disciplines within and outside of physical therapy.  Studies include laboratory, nuclear medicine, radiologic, and motion analysis.  Emphasis placed on interpretation of results as they apply to physical therapy examination and intervention.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to students accepted into professional major

courses.name: Evidence-Based Practice
courses.description: Clinical research design and methods overview. Critical review of current and historically important professional literature. Effective writing related to clinically applicable research using computer and library resources. Identification of research questions.

courses.name: Applied Therapeutic Exercise
courses.description: Application of therapeutic exercise with an emphasis on evidenced-based exercise prescription, modes and techniques of exercise typically seen in rehabilitation.

courses.name: Psychosocial Issues for Health Promotion
courses.description: Psychological and social factors impact people's health and the American Physical Therapy Association has called for interprofessional approaches for the provision of fitness, health promotion, wellness, and risk reduction programs to enhance quality of life for persons across the life-span.  This course focuses on psychosocial issues for health promotion in order to help future health care providers and scientists to improve the health and well-being of people.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to students who are admitted into the Physical Therapy-DPT program

courses.name: Bridging the Clinical-Research Gap
courses.description: This class focuses on theories of clinical decision making and Evidence-based Practice, their applications to the clinical setting and dissemination of such information to colleagues in professional forums.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Orthopedic Physical Therapy with Laboratory
courses.description: Physical therapy diagnosis, management, and prevention of disorders of the musculoskeletal system; basics of orthopedic manual therapy. Includes laboratory.

courses.name: Orthopedic Physical Therapy
courses.description: Physical therapy diagnosis, management, and prevention of disorders of the musculoskeletal system; continuation of orthopedic manual therapy emphasizing the axial skeleton; traction; massage; taping; sport-specific injury rehabilitation; orthotics.

courses.name: Pediatric Physical Therapy
courses.description: Physical therapy evaluation and treatment of children with movement dysfunction. Emphasis on therapeutic exercise.

courses.name: Rehabilitation of the Neurologically Impaired Adult
courses.description: Physical Therapy evaluation and treatment of adults who have incurred neurological deficits; emphasis on the restorative care of individuals following spinal cord injury, stroke, and traumatic head injury.

courses.name: Differential Diagnosis in Physical Therapy
courses.description: Evidence-based clinical decision making emphasizing health screenings and system review to determine physical therapy diagnosis/need for referral to other health care professionals.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to students accepted into the professional major

courses.name: Pharmacology in Rehabilitation
courses.description: Principles of pharmacology including pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicology of common drugs encountered in rehabilitation.  Emphasis on pharmacology related to the musculoskeletal, neuromuscular, cardiovascular/ pulmonary and integumentary systems across the lifespan.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to students accepted into professional major

courses.name: Assessment and Neuropsychology of Pain
courses.description: Pain is a common problem that impairs people's quality of life and costs millions of dollars annually.  Yet, an investigation of physical therapy education programs in the U.S. supported inadequate coverage of pain.  This course focuses on the assessment and neuropsychology of pain in order to help future health care providers and scientists to improve the health and well-being of people with impaired quality of life due to pain.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to students who are admitted into the Physical Therapy-DPT program

courses.name: Case Management I
courses.description: Evaluation and team approach to physical therapy management in adult medical and surgical conditions: cardiopulmonary, rheumatic, oncologic, integumentary or wound care, including major burn injury. Psychosocial and ethical issues incorporated. Problem based; laboratory.

courses.name: Clinical Education II
courses.description: Full time, supervised clinical experience addressing application of basic skills in patient evaluation and treatment, documentation and professional behaviors. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Clinical Education III
courses.description: Continuation of supervised clinical education. (Capstone course).  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Special Readings in Physical Therapy
courses.description: Independent readings selected in consultation with supervising faculty member. Identified educational goals and activities; discussion, annotated bibliography or report.

courses.name: Directed Readings in Physical Therapy
courses.description: Selected readings on specific topics.

courses.name: Clinical Evaluation and Procedures with Laboratory
courses.description: Principles and procedures of basic evaluation methods and documentation: transfers, body mechanics, muscle strength, range of motion, muscle length,  neurologic tests. Includes laboratory.  Includes discussion with emphasis on critical thinking and clinical application through problem solving.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to physical therapy students only
courses.recommendation: Successful completion of prior professional coursework

courses.name: Clinical Kinesiology with Laboratory
courses.description: Advanced Kinesiology addressing functional mobility; specifics of normal human gait; pathokinetics of gait. Assistive devices; wheelchairs; orthoses and prostheses. Includes laboratory.

courses.name: Health Policy for Physical Therapy
courses.description: This course is designed for physical therapy students and will provide an introduction to health policy along with an overview of the health care system in the United States, including its structures, financing mechanisms, and outcomes. Lecture/reflective writing/written exams. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Physical Therapy
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in physical therapy, health and wellness, prevention of disease and disability, and the rehabilitation sciences. Specific content may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Special Skills in Physical Therapy
courses.description: This course will offer a menu of options to students to develop additional knowledge about specific skills in the physical therapy profession.  Students may choose topics of interest in addition to the mandatory sessions to meet a minimum of 800 minutes of contact.  Graded on S/U basis only.  Prerequisigtes:  successful completion of prior professional coursework.

courses.name: Problems in Physical Therapy
courses.description: Independent study and development of a clinical or research paper, poster or workshop suitable for presentation in a symposium or conference. Specific plan individually developed with advisor. Journal reviews.

courses.name: Seminar in Physical Therapy
courses.description: Integrate previously learned content in unique patient cases and comprehensive review and evaluation of readiness for entry level physical therapist practice, in both didactic and psycho-motor domains. Enrollment is limited to students in professional physical therapy program.

courses.name: Professional Issues in the 21st Century
courses.description: The physical therapist as health care professional, administrator, and educator; legal, ethical, and political issues. Service delivery management; delegation of care; rural vs. urban health care needs.

courses.name: Case Management II with Laboratory
courses.description: Complex orthopedic problems in persons of all ages; supervision, reimbursement, ethical/legal situations; community programs for injury prevention; work capacity evaluation/work hardening; consultation. Problem-based format; laboratory.

courses.name: Case Management III with Laboratory
courses.description: Traditional and contemporary theories of physical therapy in advanced rehabilitation of children and adults with neurologic disorders; education/employment, ethical/legal issues; patient/client advocacy. Problem based format; laboratory.

courses.name: Clinical Education IV
courses.description: A continuation of supervised clinical education with supervision from a licensed physical therapist that has at least one year of experience. This course is a continuation of 7945 with advancing expectations of student physical therapist performance. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Clinical Education V
courses.description: Full time supervised clinical education with supervision from a licensed physical therapist that has at least one year of experience. This course is a continuation of 8945 with advancing expectations of student physical therapist performance.  Graded on S/U basis only.
